title: 113_s1414
content: The Act is titled the "Oregon Coastal Land Conveyance Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act titled the "Oregon Coastal Land Conveyance Act" defines key terms such as Federal land, planning area, and public domain land. The "Oregon Coastal Land Conveyance Act" defines key terms including public domain land as per the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, Secretary as the Secretary of the Interior, and Tribe as the Confederated Tribes of Coos, Lower Umpqua, and Siuslaw Indians. SEC. 3. CONVEYANCE. The United States conveys all right, title, and interest in Federal land to the Tribe, held in trust and part of the Tribe's reservation. A survey of boundary lines must be completed within 180 days. SEC. 4. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION. SEC. 4. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION. The Secretary will file a map and legal description of Federal land with specified committees. The filed map and legal description will have the same force as the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. The information will be available for public inspection. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. This section clarifies that existing tribal rights to land are unaffected by the Act, prohibits the export of unprocessed logs from Federal land, and restricts gaming activities on land taken into trust. SEC. 6. FOREST MANAGEMENT. Commercial forestry activities on Federal land must comply with all applicable Federal laws. SEC. 7. LAND RECLASSIFICATION. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary must identify Oregon and California Railroad land within 180 days. Public domain land of similar acreage and condition must be identified within 18 months. Maps depicting the identified land must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. After public comment, the Secretary will reclassify the land as owned by the Oregon and California Railroad. The Act of August 28, 1937 will apply to the reclassified land.
